answers.answer: Hi,How are you?There is a possibility of peripheral neuropathy also. Diabetes and vitamin B12 deficiency are common causes of peripheral neuropathy.Ulnar nerve neuropathy can cause loss of sensations in the hand.At the same time intracranial causes like brain tumor also cannot be ruled out. It would be q good idea to get a CT scan of the brain done.Hope this helps!
Thankyou.  I appreciate your advice.  I have just heard this morning from my mother that my dad has agreed to go to the hospital today, so hopefully we can get to the cause of this.  thanks again.

question: I am concerned about my 69 year old father's symptoms. He has experienced upper back pain for the past eight months and for the past two months has had worsening loss of sensation in his right hand to the extent that he has difficulty writing and drops things.  In the last week this seems to have worsened and he has also experienced altered sensations in his right foot, he states he has the sensation that one leg is shorter than the other. Yesterday he was unable to play golf (which he previously did regularly) because he felt "unco-ordinated". I have advised him to attend hospital as i suspect he needs a CT scan. His family doctor (who he attended when he started having altered sensations in his hand) thought this was a trapped nerve and referred him to an orthopedic specialist. can you give any other advice?
title: Progressive sensation loss
